text: I went to Alibaba and I bought myself one of these flip phones from China like we used to have in the 1990s with no apps, no internet connection. And then I got myself a word processor off of eBay so that I could just sit down and write and do the important stuff. And even when I stopped using all the technology, even when I got rid of all the apps, I would sit down on my desk and I'd say, "Oh, you know what? There's that book that I've been meaning what to do some research in," or, "Let me just clean off my desk real quick," or, "You know what? I should take out the trash."
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Lenny asks Nir about his personal experience with distraction and what techniques he tried. Nir explains how he attempted to solve his distraction problem by completely removing technology from his environment - buying a basic flip phone and an old word processor. However, he discovered that even without any digital distractions, he still found ways to procrastinate and avoid the important work he needed to do. This led him to realize that the root cause of distraction isn't external technology, but internal discomfort.
text_ko: 알리바바에 가서 1990년대에 쓰던 것처럼 중국산 플립폰(flip phone) 하나를 샀어요. 앱(apps)도 없고 인터넷 연결(internet connection)도 안 되는 그런 거예요. 그리고 이베이(eBay)에서 워드 프로세서(word processor)를 하나 구해서 그냥 앉아서 글만 쓰고 중요한 일만 하려고 했어요. 그런데 기술을 다 끊고 앱도 다 지웠는데도 책상에 앉으면 "아, 맞다, 내가 좀 조사해보려고 했던 그 책이 있지"라든가 "책상만 좀 치울까", "쓰레기라도 버려야겠다" 같은 생각이 자꾸 들더라고요.
text_zh: 我去阿里巴巴上给自己买了个中国产的翻盖手机，就像我们90年代用的那种，没有任何应用，也连不上网。然后我又在eBay上买了台文字处理器，这样我就能专心坐下来写东西，做真正重要的事。但是你知道吗，就算我不用那些科技产品了，就算我把所有应用都删了，我坐在桌子前还是会想："哎，对了，有本书我一直想查点资料"，或者"让我先把桌子收拾一下"，再不就是"我应该去倒个垃圾"。
text_es: Me metí a Alibaba y me compré uno de esos teléfonos de tapa de China como los que teníamos en los noventa, sin aplicaciones ni conexión a internet. Y después me conseguí un procesador de textos en eBay para poder sentarme tranquilo a escribir y hacer lo importante. Pero incluso cuando dejé de usar toda la tecnología, cuando me deshice de todas las apps, me sentaba en mi escritorio y decía: "Ah, ¿sabes qué? Ahí está ese libro en el que quería investigar algo", o "Déjame ordenar el escritorio rapidito", o "¿Sabes qué? Debería sacar la basura".

text: So, what I have adopted for myself and what I'd advise anyone who finds themselves in this situation is to always identify what is that internal trigger, what is that itch that you are looking to escape when you get distracted, because that is the source of 90% of our distractions. It's not the pings, dings, and rings. It's the feelings. But to me, that's incredibly empowering because once you realize, "Wait a minute, it's just a feeling." It's all it is, it's just an emotion. Then you can have tools ready to go. You can have arrows in your quiver ready to take out as soon as you feel that discomfort.
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir continues explaining his discovery about the true source of distraction. He reveals that research shows 90% of distractions come from internal triggers (emotions like boredom, anxiety, or discomfort) rather than external triggers like notifications. He emphasizes that understanding this is empowering because emotions are temporary and manageable. The 'arrows in your quiver' metaphor refers to having multiple strategies prepared to handle uncomfortable feelings when they arise, rather than escaping them through distraction.
text_ko: 그래서 제가 제 자신에게 적용한 방법이자 이런 상황에 처한 누구에게나 권하고 싶은 건요, 항상 그 내적 트리거(internal trigger)가 뭔지, 주의가 산만해질 때 벗어나고 싶게 만드는 그 근질거림이 뭔지 먼저 찾아보라는 거예요. 사실 우리의 산만함(distraction)의 90%는 바로 거기서 오거든요. 핑·딩·벨소리 같은 알림음 때문이 아니라 그 감정 때문이에요. 그런데 제게는 그게 오히려 엄청난 힘이 되는 깨달음이에요. '잠깐, 그냥 느낌이구나'라고 인지하면 모든 게 달라지거든요. 그러면 미리 쓸 도구들을 준비해 두고, 불편함이 느껴지자마자 꺼내 쓸 대응책들—비유하자면 화살통에 화살을 담아두는 것처럼—을 갖춰둘 수 있어요.
text_zh: 所以，我自己的做法，也是我建议任何遇到这种情况的人去做的，就是一定要搞清楚那个内在触发点(internal trigger)是什么，就是当你分心的时候，你到底想逃避的那种心里痒痒的感觉是什么，因为这才是我们90%分心的根源。不是那些手机的叮咚响声，而是我们内心的感受。但对我来说，这个发现特别有力量，因为一旦你意识到，"等等，这就是一种感觉而已。"就这么简单，就是一种情绪罢了。那你就可以准备好各种应对工具了。你可以在箭袋里准备好各种箭，一感觉到不舒服就马上拿出来用。
text_es: Entonces, lo que he adoptado para mí y lo que le recomendaría a cualquiera que se encuentre en esta situación es siempre identificar cuál es ese disparador interno (internal trigger), cuál es esa comezón de la que estás tratando de escapar cuando te distraes, porque esa es la fuente del 90% de nuestras distracciones. No son los pitidos, timbres y sonidos. Son los sentimientos. Pero para mí, eso es increíblemente empoderador porque una vez que te das cuenta de que "Oye, espera, es solo un sentimiento." Eso es todo, es solo una emoción. Entonces puedes tener herramientas listas para usar. Puedes tener flechas en tu aljaba (quiver) preparadas para sacar en cuanto sientes esa incomodidad.

text: What I tell myself is, "Okay, I'm just going to wait 10 minutes before I check email, before I scroll social media, before I Google something that is just trying to procrastinate doing the work." I can do that. I'm a grown man. I can do whatever I want. I can do that in 10 minutes. And so, for those 10 minutes, all I have to do is either get back to the task at hand, get back to writing, or surf the urge, which is simply experiencing that sensation, acknowledging, "You know what? This is hard work. That's okay. That's why I'm feeling frustrated. That's why I'm feeling bored. That's why I'm feeling anxious."
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir explains his '10-minute rule' technique for managing distraction urges. When he feels tempted to check social media or email instead of doing important work, he sets a timer for 10 minutes and tells himself he can do those distracting activities after the timer goes off - but not yet. During those 10 minutes, he either returns to his intended task or 'surfs the urge' by acknowledging and experiencing the uncomfortable emotion without trying to escape it. This technique treats the urge as temporary rather than permanent.
text_ko: 저는 스스로에게 이렇게 말해요. "좋아, 이메일 확인하기 전에, 소셜 미디어를 스크롤하기 전에, 일을 미루려고 뭔가를 구글링하기 전에 10분만 기다리자." 그 정도는 할 수 있어요. 전 어른이고 제가 하고 싶은 건 할 수 있죠. 10분이면 충분해요. 그래서 그 10분 동안 제가 할 일은 지금 하던 일로 돌아가거나 글쓰기로 다시 집중하거나, 아니면 충동을 관찰하기(urge surfing)를 하는 것뿐이에요. 그건 그 느낌을 그냥 겪으면서, "아, 이건 힘든 일이구나. 괜찮아. 그래서 답답하고 지루하고 불안한 거구나." 하고 인정하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我就跟自己说："好吧，我先等十分钟再去看邮件，再去刷社交媒体，再去谷歌搜那些其实就是在拖延正事的东西。"这个我能做到。我是个成年人了，想做什么都行，十分钟后再做这些也没问题。所以在这十分钟里，我就做两件事：要么回到手头的活儿，继续写东西；要么就让这种冲动过去，就是感受一下这种感觉，然后承认："你知道吗？这活儿确实不好干，没关系的。所以我才会觉得烦躁，觉得无聊，觉得焦虑。"
text_es: Lo que me digo es: "Bueno, voy a esperar 10 minutos antes de revisar el email, antes de meterme a redes sociales, antes de buscar algo en Google que solo es para procrastinar y no hacer el trabajo." Eso sí puedo hacerlo. Soy un adulto. Puedo hacer lo que quiera. Puedo esperar 10 minutos. Entonces, durante esos 10 minutos, lo único que tengo que hacer es volver a la tarea, regresar a escribir, o aguantar el impulso, que simplemente es sentir esa sensación y reconocer: "¿Sabes qué? Este trabajo está difícil. No pasa nada. Por eso me siento frustrado. Por eso me siento aburrido. Por eso me siento ansioso."

text: You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from. I'll say that again. You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from. So, for me, at least, when I would succumb to, "Oh, let me just check email for a quick minute, let me just see what's happening on Twitter for a quick minute," part of that was because I would justify to myself, "Well, this is a work-related task. I got to do it sometime," and there wasn't a specific time to do it on my calendar, so I would keep thinking, "Well, I got to do it sometime. Might as well just do it now."
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir discusses the importance of having a scheduled plan to identify what constitutes distraction versus traction. He explains that without a clear calendar showing what you intended to do at specific times, it becomes easy to justify any work-related activity as productive. The key insight is that even checking work email can be a distraction if it's not what you planned to do during that time block. This justification trap keeps people from focusing on their most important tasks.
text_ko: 무엇 때문에 주의가 흐트러졌는지 모르면 그걸 산만하다고 부를 수 없어요. 다시 말할게요. 무엇 때문에 주의가 흐트러졌는지 모르면 그걸 산만하다고 부를 수 없어요. 적어도 제 경우엔, "이메일 잠깐만 확인해볼까, 트위터에서 뭐 있는지 잠깐만 볼까" 하고 유혹에 넘어갈 때가 있었는데, 그 이유 중 하나는 스스로에게 "이건 업무 관련이니까 언젠가는 해야 할 일이야"라고 합리화했기 때문이에요. 근데 캘린더에 딱 정해둔 시간이 없으니 계속 "언젠가는 해야 하니까 지금 하는 게 낫지"라고 생각하게 됐던 거예요.
text_zh: 你要是不知道自己本来该干什么，就没资格说别的事情让你分心了。我再说一遍啊，你要是不知道自己本来该干什么，就没资格说别的事情让你分心了。就拿我自己来说吧，以前我总是忍不住想"哎呀，我就快速看一眼邮件，就看一分钟"，或者"我就瞄一眼推特(Twitter)上有什么动态，就一分钟"，其实很大程度上是因为我会给自己找借口，想着"这也算工作相关的事儿嘛，反正早晚得做"，但我日程表上又没专门安排时间来处理这些事，所以就老想着"反正早晚得做，不如现在就做了吧"。
text_es: No puedes decir que algo te distrajo si no sabes de qué te distrajo. Lo voy a repetir. No puedes decir que algo te distrajo si no sabes de qué te distrajo. Entonces, por lo menos en mi caso, cuando caía en el "Ah, déjame revisar el email rapidito, déjame ver qué está pasando en Twitter un momentito," parte de eso era porque me justificaba pensando, "Bueno, esto es algo relacionado con el trabajo. Lo tengo que hacer en algún momento," y como no tenía un horario específico para hacerlo en mi calendario, seguía pensando, "Bueno, lo tengo que hacer en algún momento. Mejor lo hago ahorita."

text: What you want to do instead is to book time in your schedule for this reflective work time, which is where you do the kind of work that requires you to work without distraction. Planning, strategizing, thinking, for god's sakes, can only be done without distraction. So, that fills up your calendar, as well. And what you're going to find, that there's never enough time for everything, which is good because what this forces you to do, and this is one of the main reasons why to-do lists suck, is because to-do lists have no constraints.
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir explains the importance of scheduling 'reflective work time' - periods dedicated to deep thinking, planning, and strategizing that require full attention. He distinguishes this from reactive work (responding to emails and notifications). He argues that to-do lists are inadequate because they lack time constraints - you can always add more items without considering how much time you actually have. A time-blocked calendar forces you to make realistic trade-offs and prioritize what truly matters.
text_ko: 대신 해야 할 건 이런 성찰적 작업 시간(reflective work time)을 일정에 미리 잡아두는 거예요. 이 시간에는 방해받지 않고 해야 하는 일들—계획 세우기, 전략 짜기, 정말로 깊게 생각하기 같은—을 하는 거예요. 그래서 일정도 금방 차게 돼요. 그러다 보면 모든 걸 다 할 시간은 결코 충분하지 않다는 걸 알게 될 거예요. 그런데 그게 오히려 좋은 이유는, 그게 당신에게 강제로 우선순위를 정하게 만들기 때문이에요. 이게 바로 할 일 목록(to-do lists)이 별로인 주된 이유 중 하나예요 — 할 일 목록에는 제약이 없으니까요.
text_zh: 你应该做的是在日程里专门安排时间来做这种需要深度思考的工作，就是那种必须专心致志、不能被打扰的活儿。规划啊、制定战略啊、思考问题啊，说真的，这些事儿只有在不被打扰的情况下才能做好。这样你的日历也就排满了。然后你会发现，时间永远不够用，但这其实是好事，因为这会逼着你做选择，这也是为什么待办清单(to-do list)不好用的主要原因——待办清单没有任何约束。
text_es: En cambio, lo que deberías hacer es bloquear tiempo en tu agenda para este trabajo de reflexión, que es donde haces el tipo de trabajo que necesita que te concentres sin distracciones. Planificar, crear estrategias, pensar, ¡por Dios!, solo se puede hacer sin distracciones. Así que esto también te va a llenar el calendario. Y lo que vas a descubrir es que nunca hay tiempo suficiente para todo, lo cual está bien porque esto te obliga a hacer algo, y esta es una de las razones principales por las que las listas de pendientes no sirven: porque las listas de pendientes no tienen límites.

text: You don't tell your boss no, you ask your boss to help you prioritize. That is your boss' most important job is to prioritize. So, you're not saying no. You're saying, "Here's my calendar. Here's this list of stuff you've asked me to do. Help me prioritize." And here's what's going to happen. Your boss is going to look at your calendar and say, "You know what? That meeting, you really don't need to be at that meeting. But that thing on that piece of paper that you listed over here, that's way more important. Can you swap that out?"
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir addresses how to manage competing demands from your manager without saying 'no' directly. He calls this technique 'schedule syncing' or 'managing your manager.' Instead of refusing requests, you show your boss your time-blocked calendar and a separate list of additional tasks they've requested. You then ask them to help prioritize what's most important. This approach leverages the fact that prioritization is a key management responsibility while giving you control over your time.
text_ko: 상사한테 그냥 "안 돼요"라고 말하는 게 아니라, 상사에게 우선순위(prioritize)를 정해 달라고 요청하는 거예요. 사실 상사의 가장 중요한 역할 중 하나가 우선순위를 정하는 거예요. 그러니까 당신은 "아니요"라고 하는 게 아니라, "여기 제 캘린더예요. 여기 요청하신 업무 목록도 있어요. 우선순위를 도와주세요."라고 말하는 거예요. 그럼 어떻게 될까요? 상사가 캘린더를 보면서 "사실 그 회의에는 굳이 안 가도 돼요. 그런데 여기 적어둔 이 일이 훨씬 더 중요하네요. 그걸로 바꿔줄 수 있나요?"라고 말해 줄 거예요.
text_zh: 你不要直接跟老板说不行，而是要请老板帮你排个优先级。其实排优先级就是老板最重要的工作之一。所以你不是在拒绝，而是在说："老板你看，这是我的日程表，这是你让我做的那些事儿，你帮我理理头绪吧。" 然后会发生什么呢？你老板会看看你的安排，然后说："你知道吗，那个会议你其实不用参加。但是你这里写的这件事儿，这个重要多了。你能把时间调一下吗？"
text_es: A tu jefe no le dices que no, le pides que te ayude a priorizar. Esa es la función más importante de tu jefe: establecer prioridades. O sea, no estás diciendo que no. Estás diciendo: "Mira, aquí tienes mi agenda. Esta es la lista de todo lo que me has pedido que haga. Ayúdame a priorizar." ¿Y sabes qué va a pasar? Tu jefe va a ver tu agenda y te va a decir: "¿Sabes qué? Esa reunión, realmente no necesitas estar en esa reunión. Pero esto que pusiste aquí en tu lista, esto es muchísimo más importante. ¿Puedes cambiar una cosa por la otra?"

text: The antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. The antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. Fundamentally, distraction is an impulse control issue. That's all it is, and it's a skill like any other. We learn skills. Why do we expect that we should just be born with this innate skill to fight distraction? It's a skill like any other. And so, the antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. If we plan ahead, if we know that we're going to take steps a day to prevent getting distracted tomorrow, there's no distraction we can't overcome.
speaker: Nir Eyal
context: Nir provides his core philosophy for becoming indistractable. He emphasizes that distraction is fundamentally about impulse control, which is a learnable skill rather than an inherent character trait. His key insight is that the solution lies in planning ahead - taking deliberate steps today to prevent tomorrow's distractions. This forward-thinking approach empowers people to take control of their attention rather than feeling helpless against distraction.
text_ko: 충동성에 대한 해독제는 사전 숙고(forethought)예요. 본질적으로 산만함은 충동 조절(impulse control)의 문제예요. 그게 전부고, 다른 기술(skill)들처럼 배워야 하는 능력이에요. 우리는 기술을 배워요. 왜 산만함을 이겨내는 이런 능력을 그냥 타고나야 한다고 생각하죠? 다른 기술과 다르지 않아요. 그래서 충동성에 대한 해독제는 사전 숙고예요. 미리 계획하고, "내일 산만해지지 않도록 이런 조치를 취하겠다"고 정해두면 못 이길 산만함이 없어요.
text_zh: 冲动的解药就是提前想好。冲动的解药就是提前想好。说白了，分心就是个自控力的问题，就这么简单，这跟其他技能一样。技能都是学出来的嘛。我们凭什么觉得自己天生就该有对抗分心的本事？这就是个技能，跟别的技能没什么两样。所以说，冲动的解药就是提前想好。如果我们提前规划，如果我们知道今天要采取一些措施来防止明天分心，那就没有克服不了的分心。
text_es: El remedio para ser impulsivo es pensar las cosas antes. En el fondo, distraerse es un tema de autocontrol, nada más. Es una habilidad como cualquier otra. Las habilidades se aprenden. ¿Por qué esperamos nacer ya sabiendo cómo luchar contra las distracciones? Es una habilidad como cualquier otra. Entonces, el remedio para ser impulsivo es pensar las cosas antes. Si planificamos con tiempo, si sabemos que vamos a tomar medidas hoy para no distraernos mañana, no hay distracción que no podamos vencer.
